dataset.title: Lakes of Missouri Volunteer Program (LMVP) and University of Missouri: Missouri Statewide Lake Assessment Data (MO-SLAP), 1978-2013

creator.organizationName: Fisheries and Wildlife Department, University of Missouri

abstract.para: The Lakes of Missouri Volunteer Program (LMVP) is funded by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency through the Missouri Department of Natural Resources and coordinated by the School of Natural Resources at the University of Missouri. It was created in 1992 and began with four lakes in the Kansas City area. Since then about 200 volunteers have participated and water samples have been collected on over 50 different lakes around the state. The goals of the LMVP are: 1) to determine the current water quality based on productivity or trophic state of Missouri's lakes, 2) to monitor for changes in water quality over time, and 3) to educate the public about lake ecology and water quality issues. Volunteers take water samples to measure algae, nitrogen, phosphorus, inorganic suspended solids, and measure Secchi transparency in the field. Many lakes have several sample sites. The water samples are analyzed at the University of Missouri-Columbia, Department of Fisheries and Wildlife limnology laboratory. An annual data report is compiled containing the results of the data from all of the public lakes. This report is sent to all interested parties including the volunteers, government agencies and lake associations. The process starts in the spring when an LMVP staff and volunteer meet at the lake. The volunteer is given all of the equipment and trained by the staff on the proper collection and processing procedures.

section.title: Lab methods
section.para: Total Phosphorus (ug/L): Total phosphorus samples are analyzed with a Spectronic Genysis 2 UV/VIS Spectrophotometer. Standard curves were created daily, running known standards and spikes with each group of samples and correcting for background turbidity using a 3-point drop correction. Blanks were run during every run, calibration checks preformed at beginning and end, 4 standards plus a blank were used in creating standard curves, and 2 replicates were run for each sample.

Total Nitrogen as N (mg/L): Total nitrogen samples are analyzed with a Spectronic Genysis 2 UV/VIS Spectrophotometer using the second derivative ultraviolet spectroscopy method (Crumpton et al., 1992). Blanks were run during every run, calibration checks preformed at beginning and end, 4 standards plus a blank were used in creating standard curves, and 2 replicates were run for each sample.
 Method: APHA, Sartory and Grobbelar, and Knowlton

Non-Volatile Sus Solids (mg/L): APHA_2540-D; APHA_2540-E Total suspended solids samples are collected on a rinsed, dried, ashed and weighted filter (Whatman 934-AH for older projects or Gelman GFC for newer projects). Usually 500 mL of well-mixed water is filtered through each filter, but sometimes less if clogging occurs. Two filters are processed for each sample. Filters are frozen until analysis. For analysis, filters are dried (in an aluminum boat in a 105C drying oven), weighed, ashed, and reweighed. Detection limit (0.5mg/L) http://oewri.missouristate.edu/assets/OEWRI/TSSolids.pdf

section.title: Secchi depth
section.para: SECCHI (m): “Secchi disk measurements are one of the most widely used measurements of water clarity. It is important that your boat is not drifting while you take the Secchi reading. Always take the Secchi reading on the shaded side of the boat. Doing the reading on the shaded side of the boat is important, because sun glare off the water will affect the accuracy of your reading. Please do not use any physical aids such as diving masks at the water surface to take your reading; this will make your Secchi readings non-comparable to readings from other lakes. If you are wearing sunglasses you make keep them on while you take your reading but we ask that you try to wear them for all readings to maintain consistency. Secure the end of the Secchi disk line to your boat to avoid losing it overboard. Lower the Secchi disk into the water until you cannot see it anymore. At this point you will place a clothes pin on the line at the waters surface to mark the depth at which the disk disappeared. Lower the Secchi disk a foot or two deeper, then start to raise it back until you can see it. Mark this depth with a clothes pin pin at the surface of the water. The average of these two depths is your Secchi reading.”

section.para: "All samples were collected and processed by trained volunteers, then analyzed by University of Missouri staff.” (LMVP 2010 Data Report)

description.para: The Lakes of Missouri Volunteer Program, with the help of volunteer monitors, tracks nonpoint source pollution in Missouri’s lakes by measuring chlorophyll (a measure of algal biomass), nitrogen and phosphorus (nutrients), suspended sediments (soil particles), and water clarity. Sampling includes monitoring over fifty different lakes around the state

samplingDescription.para: MVP volunteers monitor at 3-week intervals from late spring to early fall and process the samples in their homes. The processed samples are stored in volunteers’ freezers until LMVP staff can pick them up. The samples are then analyzed at the University of Missouri’s Limnology laboratory following accepted standard methods. LMVP data are “research quality”, and have been used in several scientific journal articles. One study (Obrecht et al. 1998) shows LMVP data to be of comparable quality to data collected by employees of the University of Missouri. Collection sites on lakes: On lakes where there is only one sample taken, this site is generally near the middle of the dam and away from the shore in deeper water. On lakes where there are multiple sites, such as Table Rock or Lake of the Ozarks, volunteers choose sites that are conveniently located for them.
